body:
@icefury71

Breaking down to tasks
1. Abstract segment fetcher layer to be pluggable to support different segment fetchers (http/s3/hdfs/webhdfs).
2. Implement webhdfs segment fetcher.
3. Add a new segment push protocol on controller to accept segment metadata Json only. Need to double check with existing validation logic to make sure it won't break that.
4. Modify existing segment push job to POST segment metadata Json with a corresponding download url.
close as already pushed.
Any comparison with Druid?
Just say it's similar with some enhancement and give credit to Druid community and move forward  :)

This was already fixed, just updated github

Merged, travis failures are because of another issue that is already fixed in another commit.
Going to split this PR
How do you plan to use this interface. I am not sure the interface is clear. Why does it take Object?. Should we use DateTime object instead?

same:
select \* from baseballStats limit 10,20
10 is the offset, 20 is the number of rows.

but it don't work well,
I run the sql(select \* from test order by time desc limit 10,20)in shell, 
it returned different results every time.

There is no global docId specified in Pinot.
If you want same results, you can try "select \* from baseballStats order by [some column] limit 10,20".

@fx19880617  thanks! how about the paging which contains group by condition?
`/*Top 5 run scorers of the year 2000*/`
`select sum('runs') from baseballStats where yearID=2000 group by playerName top 5 limit 0`
it returned top 5 records, Bug if I want to get 5 to 10 records?
`select sum('runs') from baseballStats where yearID=2000 group by playerName limit 5,5`
but it default returned top 10, This is not correct

Pinot does not support pagination for aggregation/group

convertor looks good but few things are missing. This conversion should be applicable to both realtime and offline. We added transformer to transform data types. We should add this logic to the same place.
I am thinking if its better to templatize the converter Converter<IncomingPinotDataType, OutgoingPinotDataType>. But this can be done in another PR.
is this diff from master? looks like diff from the previous PR. Can you confirm. This is looking better.
Yes, this is one commit ahead master.
LGTM. Minor comments.

Few other thoughts
1. It would be great to include a flag or some property in the response to indicate that the response came from the cache. This will help in future debugging.
2. User should be able to bypass the cache by passing in a request flag / property. 
3. Not sure what you plan to store in the cache, but consider the performance of serialization / deserizalation of objects in cache. Sometimes it might be better to store the raw serialized version from the server cache to avoid overhead. This is a perf optimization and can be prioritized for a later time.
4. What happens to cached rows if the underlying segments expire or gets deleted?
5. It will be good to list out the cache invalidation scenarios. May be to begin with it is purely time based?
Merged.
LGTM.
LGTM. Will merge.

This can be caused by running out of mmap or file handles. On Linux, you can change the `vm.max_map_count` sysctl to increase the number of files that can be mmap'ed concurrently and the `fs.file-max` sysctl to increase the number of files that can be open concurrently. This will be alleviated when we merge all columns from a segment into a segment file, which should be coming soon.
Close as already merged
LGTM, I'll merge it later today. I'll amend the commit message to say "Adding method to stop all Kafka consumers," as there is no shutdown hook in this code.

I thought there was another option to initialize it with Zookeeper and we
would listen to EXTERNAVIEW. Looks like that not the case.

> have issues.
> Any plan to fix this?
> Some possible solutions:
> 1. putting data change listener on /EXTERNALVIEW/brokerResource and update
> broker list when change happens;
> 2. retry on other nodes + active fetch online broker list when fails
>

Hi, I checked at the exception stacktrace, and it seems that the exception was thrown out from ObjectMapper when trying to read value from schema json file. I tried it locally and it reads the value correctly. Can you please first retry with the latest version pinot? If that still does not work, can you provide more details on what command you run?

Close was unintentional. Commenting to reopen for merge.
LGTM

From user/concurrency point of view:
â€¢ Is there a limitation for concurrent users running queries?

No, other than hardware limits. Some Pinot clusters at Linkedin process several thousands of queries per second.

â€¢ In case I need to add more users, what is the cost? (More hardware/servers/memory?)

Add more hardware, it scales near-linearly.

From data point of view:
â€¢ Is there a limitation on how many dimensions/lookup tables I can design? Is there any kind of performance implications?

Tables are independent, there's no real performance implication to adding tables (as long as you're not planning on having thousands of tables, at least, zk may be a contention point with that many tables). Judging from your question though, it seems as if you're doing a star schema-style design. Pinot doesn't support joins, so you should flatten your dimensions into the table itself.

â€¢ What will be the cost of adding another dimension/lookup table? (More hardware/servers/memory or redesign of the solution?)

See above, no joins.

â€¢ What about the history, as I mention before we are talking about one year retention, but if I need to add more retention time, example 3 years, what will be the implication?

It'll increase query latency if those rows need to be scanned as part of query execution. If they don't need to be, then they're nearly free (they get rejected quickly at query processing time).

From Programming point of view:
â€¢ Are the windows functions supported? 

Not at the moment. Windowing functions require a second pass during query execution and can be implemented on the client side.

â€¢ If not, is there a workaround for it?

Compute them on the client side.

â€¢ If partially, which one is supported or not supported.
â€¢ Are Joins between tables supported? (Is there a limitation for table size?)

No, and we don't foresee adding support for them this year.

â€¢ Are nested queries supported?

No, and we don't foresee adding support for them this year.

â€¢ Are functions like Count, sum, avg., max, min, etc. supported? How is it working with uniqueness? (Count (distinct X), Sum (distinct X), etc.)

Aggregate functions (count, sum, min, max, avg) are supported. You can do `select distinctCount(X)` for distinct count, `select distinctCountHLL(X)` for HyperLogLog approximation. 

â€¢ Are ranking functions, like in MSSQL, supported? (row_number, rank, dense_tank, ntile)

No, and we don't foresee adding support for them this year.

â€¢ How Pinot is supporting the comparison between populations? Example, I need to get the population of users which didnâ€™t purchase in the last 3 days but they click on my site at least 1 times. (when purchase and click are different events types in the system)

Put both events in the same table as part of your ETL process, roll up the rows on Hadoop, `select sum(clickCount), sum(purchaseCount) where date >= 20160325 group by userId`

â€¢ Flexibility from integration point of view (could it work with Java/python/etc.)

We have a Java API and a REST API for other languages.

LGTM

I will merge once travis passes

LGTM

I will merge once travis clears it
Java changes LGTM. @MarthaWB can you review the UI changes?
LGTM

+1 for the feature. Are there any other alternatives other than forcing current segment to be flushed?
LGTM
lgtm

+1 for the feature. It seems low cost to force the current segment to be
flushed. This would be an issue only if we upgrade the schema often, which
is not usual.

On Fri, Jun 3, 2016 at 11:51 PM, Kishore Gopalakrishna <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> +1 for the feature. Are there any other alternatives other than forcing
> current segment to be flushed?
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/linkedin/pinot/issues/151#issuecomment-223740505, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AIUJl97b027zfzPjy0-ppy5L8AljAYilks5qISB6gaJpZM4IuEOs
> .

The other alternative I can think of is to drop current in_progress segment then restart it.
For this, we need to reinit kafka consumer to make sure we are consuming from the offsets that previous segment committed.

Wouldn't dropping the current segment cause queries to give inconsistent
results during the time that the realtime segment catches up? What is the
benefit in dropping the segment over just moving to a new segment? Aren't
previous segments still with the old schema?

In the current code, it just sends out the query to all segments. The segments are pruned quickly at the beginning of the query phase in the case of a query with time boundaries, as the time column cannot contain data that matches the predicate.

The routing table is built at https://github.com/linkedin/pinot/blob/32a5f91cf02e33314d6c1e2c2d823eecc0accc6f/pinot-transport/src/main/java/com/linkedin/pinot/routing/builder/BalancedRandomRoutingTableBuilder.java#L40-L40
